item.title: How to Get the Hammerhead Choppa in Fortnite
item.description:
The Hammerhead Choppa allows players to take to the skies, swarming against bugs and other players alike as they hold ground from above. If players want to use helicopters in Fortnite , then the Hammerhead Choppa is the vehicle for them, especially since it has space for everyone on your squad, and even hovers when nobody is in the pilot's seat. If you're looking for Hammerhead Choppa locations in Fortnite , or simply want to know how to fly this thing, then check out the guide below.

Hammerhead Choppa Locations in Fortnite

The Hammerhead Choppa can be found at 4 specific spots on the Battle Royale island. Here's the location of every Hammerhead Choppa in Fortnite :

  • O.X.R. HQ
  • Outpost north of The Hive
  • Outpost north of Canyon Crossing
  • Outpost west of Kappa Kappa Factory

How to Use the Hammerhead Choppa in Fortnite

The Hammerhead Choppa is an air vehicle in Fortnite that has a total of 1,620 durability before it's destroyed. This large vehicle can carry a total of 5 players, with 4 in the back that can use their weapons, and one in the driver's seat. The interesting gimmick of the Hammerhead Choppa is that the driver can switch seats to shoot with their allies, while the Hammerhead Choppa remains in a hover mode for around 15 seconds. This way, solo players can easily complete their quest to hit opponents beyond 50 meters while in the Hammerhead Choppa, as they do not need to be flying it to shoot from it .

Here's a list of the Hammerhead Choppa controls for console and PC:

  • Move Up: R2/RT/Left-Click or X/A/Space
  • Move Down: L2/LT/Right-Click
  • Boost (Hold): Circle/B/Left Shift
  • Switch Seat: R3/Left Ctrl
  • Exit (Hold): Square/X/E
  • Loudspeaker: D-Pad Down/B

The Hammerhead Choppa has plenty of durability to tank enemy fire, but the other problem lies in the fuel consumption. The Hammerhead Choppa consumes fuel with movement, and more if players use the Boost function. If the Hammerhead Choppa runs out of fuel mid-flight, it will crash to the ground and explode, so it's best to know when to abandon the vehicle or refuel at gas stations and vehicle pads found across Burd to Go, Outposts, and O.X.R. HQ.

item.title: How to Get the Roly Poly in Fortnite
item.description:
The Roly Poly has arrived, providing players with an ally within the bug swarms of Fortnite Chapter 6 Season 4. The swarm might be deadly, but the Roly Poly is a cuddly bug who means no harm and simply wants to bounce around at high speeds with a friend to keep them company. If players are looking to make the most of this mobility item in Fortnite , or they simply want to find all locations of the Roly Poly, then they can check out the guide below.

Roly Poly Locations in Fortnite

The Roly Poly is a bug vehicle that can be found in random spots around the Battle Royale map, but there are spawns that are more consistent than others. In general, players are going to want to check around Infected Outposts and Bug Nests for the Roly Poly, and here are some easy Roly Poly locations for each match:

  • Dystopia City
  • The Hive
  • Ranger's Ruin
  • Demon's Debris
  • North of Canyon Crossing
  • North of Outpost Enclave
  • West of Supernova Academy
  • South of O.X.R. HQ

How to Use the Roly Poly

The Roly Poly is a living bug that players can interact with to jump inside, where they will then take control of this oversized bug to perform fast movement with plenty of bounces, hops, and shockwave effects. The Roly Poly is incapable of damaging enemies, and players can only use it as a vehicle in which they can get to areas fast through these controls:

  • Bounce: R2/RT/Left-Click (Tap)
  • Dive Bounce: R2/RT/Left-Click (Tap in Air)
  • Increase Weight / Rev Up: R2/RT/Left-Click (Hold)
  • Exit: Square/X/F

The Roly Proly is pretty fast, especially if players are timing their dive bounces correctly. However, it's worth noting that if the Roly Poly has been shot, then it will get scared, and players are ejected from its protective shell. In cases like this, players will want to interact with the Roly Poly to soothe it. The best way to use the Roly Poly is to use it as a mobility item and jump out of it in mid-air to get the height on unsuspecting opponents, as there is no fall damage from exiting the Roly Poly.

item.title: New Steam Games For Fans Of Roman & Greek Mythology
item.description:
Summary

  • Ancient Greek and Roman myths power diverse new games across genres and styles.
  • Sequels and remakes ( Hades 2, Titan Quest 2, Age of Mythology: Retold ) modernize mythic gameplay.
  • Indie and AAA titles reimagine myth: darker, sci-fi, tactical, and survival spins reshape familiar legends.

The myths of ancient Rome and Greece have captivated storytellers for centuries, and modern games keep finding fresh new ways to retell those tales of gods, mortals, and monsters. Whether it’s stepping into the shoes of legendary heroes or uncovering unknown civilizations inspired by ancient tales, some new releases are breathing fresh life into those old stories.

These games don’t just toss in a Zeus or Hades reference and call it quits; they weave the deepest parts of the mythology into their gameplay, story, and world design in all sorts of clever and surprising ways. From roguelikes to metroidvanias to reimagined city-building legends, some of them are in Early Access, others dropped within the past year. Here are some new Steam games that carry the torch of mythology into modern gaming.

Titan Quest 2

A Titan Returns To Claim Its Throne

The Diablo- esque, god-slaying escapade from 2006 finally gets a sequel all these years later. Titan Quest 2 brings the original’s myth-soaked world back into the spotlight, this time in high definition and with modern features. Keeping the spirit of the first game, the sequel adds a much-needed coat of polish, makes the combat snappier for a more responsive experience, and adds modern RPG elements.

The story centers around Nemesis, the goddess of retribution, as she tries to twist fate itself as players unravel her influence. What makes the game shine is how combat manages to feel both precise and chaotic at the same time, as players fight against hordes of cyclops, satyrs, and hydras with all sorts of varied builds. The class system from the original game returns, letting players combine mythic archetypes into new hybrid builds, letting them create characters that feel like heroes pulled from a forgotten epic.

Hades 2

When Death Takes A Coffee Break

Supergiant Games made a biblical splash with their Greek-inspired roguelike back in 2020, and even though we haven’t seen the full thing yet, it seems like their sequel has captured that lightning in a bottle. Still in Early Access, Hades 2 doubles down on everything that made its predecessor so beloved. Instead of Zagreus, the protagonist this time is Melinoë, daughter of Hades, as players follow her on her mission to take on the Titan of Time, Chronos. This new angle brings a fresh perspective while still carrying the on-point narrative writing and fluid gameplay that made the original such a hit.

Each run feels both like a fight against bosses and a family reunion with meddling gods who always find an excuse to hand out blessings... or curses. Hades 2 is shaping up to be a perfect sequel with how it evolves and builds upon the mechanics of the first game without making things overwhelming. Magic plays a much bigger role now, with Melinoë weaving spells in between weapon attacks, and new traversal options shake up how players can approach each chamber. Dying over and over is still the mainstay of the experience, though, because in Greek myth, stories change with every retelling.

Dawn Of Defiance

An Indie Odyssey With A Dark Edge

Dawn of Defiance blends tactical RPG combat with a reimagining of Rome’s collapse, embellishing it with stories of gods, demigods, and monsters influencing the fate of mortals. Players lead a scrappy group of rebels across a fallen empire, with a story that’s steeped in mythic undertones and choices that can shift the balance of power.

The game’s structure relies heavily on strategic battles, where positioning and timing are just as important as the weapons that soldiers wield. However, its charm is in the vibes and atmosphere, where each ruined temple and blood-soaked battlefield feels haunted by oft-told stories. Though it may not have the big-budget presentation of some of the other games on this list, Dawn of Defiance really taps into the raw themes of fate, rebellion, and the cold cruelty of the divine in a refreshingly new way.

Somber Echoes

Echoes Of A Myth Reimagined

On the surface, Somber Echoes looks like a sci-fi horror metroidvania, but a closer look reveals a world deeply rooted in mythology. The game wonderfully reinterprets Greek and Roman underworld imagery through a spacefaring lens. Players navigate through derelict ships and alien ruins where mythological influences ooze from every pixel. Monsters are inspired by chimeras and shades of the dead, all reimagined with a horrific, sci-fi edge. This marriage of mythology and cosmic horror gives rise to something that feels both familiar and utterly strange at the exact same time.

What makes the game stand out is how it perfectly blends exploration and survival. Combat forces players to think tactically, requiring them to conserve resources as they face all sorts of grotesque beings while uncovering lore scattered across futuristic logs and ancient artifacts. It’s a unique twist on the mythical formula, borrowing less from grandiose tales of heroism and focusing more on the darker side, where wandering too far into unknown realms means never, ever coming back. The name is fitting; these are echoes of old legends distorted into something uncomfortable.

Age Of Mythology: Retold

Legends Never Die

For real-time strategy fans, Age of Mythology: Retold isn’t so much a new chapter as it is a full-on revival. The original game has held cult status ever since its release, 23 years ago. Now with a fresh coat of paint, players can once again summon gods and mythical beasts to fight alongside soldiers and siege weapons. The remake sharpens up the visuals, reworks the UI, and updates some of the more dated systems without losing the heart of what made the original so iconic. It’s a proper monument to one of the gaming greats.

The Greek, Norse, and Egyptian pantheons return in full force, carrying divine powers that can suddenly shift the tides of a match. There’s an inexplicable joy in dropping a meteor shower mid-battle or calling forth a squad of Minotaurs to trample an army, and Age of Mythology: Retold keeps all that intact while adding balance tweaks for modern players. It’s definitive proof that myths never really age; they just need to be retold to remind us why they mattered in the first place.

item.title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 Ditching Carry Forward Feature
item.description:
Activision has made the surprise announcement that the Carry Forward feature will not be returning for the upcoming Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 . Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 is set to launch on November 14 and looks to be a faithful entry in the long-running series. As usual, Call of Duty fans can expect Black Ops 7 to feature a story campaign, online multiplayer, and Zombies.

Unfortunately, the Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 reveal hasn't gone as well as Activision may have hoped. The Black Ops 7 campaign trailer from Gamescom has been flooded with dislikes, and fans upset with the latest Black Ops 6 updates have expressed their concern that the new game will follow a similar path of adding cartoony crossover cosmetics that don't fit with the game's tone. Activision has acknowledged these concerns and announced that content from Black Ops 6 will not be available in Black Ops 7 as previously planned.

Black Ops 7 Will Be More Mindful About Cosmetics

The Carry Forward feature, which lets players bring their skins and weapons from previous Call of Duty games to new entries, is not coming back for Black Ops 7 . " Black Ops 7 needs to feel authentic to Call of Duty and its setting," Activision said. This means none of the Black Ops 6 Operators, skins, or weapons will be available in Black Ops 7 . However, Double XP tokens and GobbleGums are excluded and will be carried forward to the new game. Black Ops 6 content will remain available to use in Call of Duty: Warzone , as this change only applies to Black Ops 7 . "In Black Ops 7 , bundles and items will be crafted to fit the Black Ops identity. We hear the feedback. We need to deliver a better balance toward the immersive, core Call of Duty experience."

Activision also addressed some of the other controversies plaguing Call of Duty as of late, like the ongoing cheater problems. Starting with Black Ops 7 , PC players will have to enable Secure Boot and TPM 2.0, which will make it easier for Activision to "block cheats at the system level." Activision will also be introducing "new detection and mitigation systems" to kick cheaters "earlier and harder." Some of these anti-cheat capabilities will be tested during the Black Ops 7 open beta period.

The Black Ops 7 beta will start with an early access period on October 2, available to those that pre-order the game and anyone signed up for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate/PC Game Pass. Then, a proper Black Ops 7 open beta available to everyone will kick off on October 5. The Black Ops 7 beta will be live through October 8. Call of Duty fans can look forward to more information on the beta, the game's multiplayer functionality, and what Zombies is bringing to the table at the Call of Duty NEXT event on September 30.

item.title: One Dune: Awakening Class Is Virtually Unbeatable
item.description:
As is the case with almost any MMO, Dune: Awakening 's classes are a core part of its gameplay. Some lean into raw utility, others into strategy or resource control, but most importantly, each one feels unique enough to push players toward a specific style of play. Truthfully, it's what makes comparing them so interesting, because no two are meant to excel in exactly the same way. That being said, there is one class in Dune: Awakening that might stand above the others for its well-roundedness.

While it can be hard to argue whether any class in Dune: Awakening is objectively the "best" (as much of it comes down to a player's preferred playstyle and skill), each class does have certain strengths and weaknesses that might position it above the rest, so long as it is played correctly. On that note, of the five classes currently available to players in Dune: Awakening , one stands out as potentially the game's most dominant class, simply on account of its blend of speed, damage output, and versatility across PvE, PvP, and solo play. That class is none other than the Swordmaster.

Dune: Awakening's Swordmaster Might Be the Game's Most Dominant Class

Swordmaster's Strengths Across PvE and PvP

What's most interesting about the Swordmaster's reputation as the class to beat is that Dune: Awakening 's melee combat has always been one of its biggest criticisms, and that is what the Swordmaster, as its name implies, is all about. Built for aggressive melee combat, the Swordmaster is agile and can deal considerable single-target damage, allowing players to tear through most of the game's PvE content with relative ease. Heavy armor builds then increase the class' survivability, although its stamina-driven combat mechanics still demand player attentiveness. So, for Dune: Awakening solo players, this makes it a standout option, as most encounters can be tackled without a group.

The Swordmaster doesn't just dominate PvE content either, as it is perhaps even more viable in Dune: Awakening 's PvP gameplay. The Swordmaster has become famous for being able to wipe out other players in a single spice-buffed attack, which is largely why tier lists consistently place it in S-rank for both PvE and PvP. Mobility-focused tools like Knee Charge and Weirding Step make the Swordmaster difficult to pin down as well, and when combined with its melee proficiency, it can pretty much dictate the pace and outcome of almost any fight. Of course, again, it takes a bit of mastery to get to this point.

How It Compares to Planetologist and Other Classes

None of this is to say that the Swordmaster is perfect by any means, though. Since it is a melee-based class, its reliance on close quarters makes it vulnerable at range, and its stamina-heavy playstyle can punish players who are swinging their weapon around carelessly. Still, when measured against the rest of Dune: Awakening 's lineup, few others come close to its balance of solo viability and group utility. The Planetologist, for example, can be great for resource and support options, but it can't rival the Swordmaster in combat. Then there's Dune: Awakening 's Mentat, which is highly beginner-friendly but still lacks the offensive edge of the Swordmaster.

In the end, it's the Swordmaster's ability to perform well across multiple fronts — whether it be soloing Dune: Awakening 's Deep Desert, tackling duels, or making valuable contributions to group PvP — that makes it virtually unbeatable in the current meta. Of course, since Dune: Awakening is a live-service game, this meta is expected to change regularly over time, especially if and when new classes are added in the future. For now, though, the Swordmaster reigns.
